newsitem.title: USA: BMW to overhaul U.S. dealer network - WSJ.
newsitem.headline: BMW to overhaul U.S. dealer network - WSJ.

text.p: Bayerische Motoren-Werke AG wants to make buying BMW cars easier and more customer-friendly, in an attempt to double its share of the U.S. market, the Wall Street Journal said.
In Thursday's electronic edition, the Journal said BMW is launching an overhaul of its U.S. dealer network that includes revamping its vehicle distribution and retailing activities.
Victor Doolan, president of BMW's North American marketing unit, told the Journal that he wants to cut distribution costs to 24 percent of the sticker price from about 29 percent by the year 2000.

"If we don't move away from the traditional way of selling cars, customers are going to move from us," Doolan said. "Retailers have to concentrate on developing a viable preowned business and bonding in such a personal way that customers will want to come only to that franchise."

BMW's new retailing program has been brought out to five of its 350 dealerships, featuring a single "customer counselor" assigned to each car being sold. That's in contrast to three people -- a salesman, manager and finance officer -- who are typically involved in each sale.
If BMW dealers go along with the new structure, Doolan said he believes the company can increase its market share in the U.S. to at least 1.5 percent. It currently has a market share of 0.8 percent.
